title: Protocol for using autoclaved intertidal sediment as a medium to enrich marine cable bacteria
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Prepare autoclaved sediment and seawater in a laboratory
Timing: 1 day
The following procedure describes the steps required to prepare autoclaved sediment from aliquots of the sediment previously harvested.
As was done for incubations, sieve the stored sediment through a 0.5 mm mesh screen to remove large fauna, rocks, and debris.
Homogenize the sieved sediment by physical mixing. Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Note: Oxygen exposure can be reduced during the homogenization process by introducing a tube that flows nitrogen gas into the sediment.
Fill 100 mL autoclave-safe glass bottles with homogenized sediment to about ¾ of the volume.
Fill 1000 mL autoclave-safe bottles with seawater to about ¾ of the volume.
Note: Sterilized artificial seawater can be used as well.
Autoclave the glass bottles at 120°C for 1–2 h.
Allow the autoclaved sediment and seawater to cool down to about 25°C before use.
Note: Autoclaved sediment can also be stored and sealed at about 25°C until inoculation. The containers remain sealed and are stored in a cool place, for up to two weeks in this study.
Critical: The homogenization of sulfidic sediment and mishandling of iron sulfide may release hydrogen sulfide, a highly toxic chemical in its gaseous form. We again recommend the use of personal protective equipment such as a sulfide-specific face respirator when in enclosed spaces, and the homogenization process should be conducted under a ventilation hood or in an open well-ventilated space. The autoclaved sediment and seawater should be prepared at least one day to two weeks ahead of the following steps.
Alternatives: Nitrogen gas can be replaced by other inert gases such as helium and argon.
Extract cable bacteria filaments from the cultured natural sediment
Timing: 2 h

The following procedure describes the steps required to isolate CB filaments from the cultured natural sediment matrix.
Take sub-cores (sediment plugs approximately 0.5 cm in diameter and 1 cm long) from the cultured sediment by using cut-off 1 mL syringes (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1891-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Graphical demonstration of the preparation of a cut-off syringe
Left: cutting the tip of the 1cc syringe to allow the proper intake of a sediment plug (the red line indicates where to make the cut); right: the finished look of the cut-off syringe.
Reduce the sediment volume around the sampled mass of CB filaments by gentle washing Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Place the extracted plugs of sediment in a glass Petri dish.
Add seawater or artificial seawater to the Petri dish.
Gently shake the Petri dish to allow the sediment particles to separate from the CB filaments.
Remove sediment-laden water from the Petri dish.
Repeat b–d until the filamentous structure of CB can be observed, and the amount of adhering sediment grains can no longer be reduced (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]).
Note: Deionized water can be used in this step as well.
Use the fabricated glass hook to pick CB filaments from the remainder of the washed sediment plug(s). Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Push the hook gently into a suboxic zone of the remaining washed sample, which can be identified by its grayish color.
Swirl the hook gently several times (3–7).
Slowly pull the hook away from the sample and look for filamentous structures of CB connecting (extending between) the hook and the remainder of the sediment.
Collect the filaments by pulling the hook apart from the sediment (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1891-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. The stratified zonation of topmost sediment inhabited by cable bacteria

Note: After being pulled out from the sediment, a mass of CB will shrink onto the hook and appear like a “glob”.
Critical: Samples should be taken from cultured sediments which have developed a pronounced suboxic zone evident by color changes from black to gray and the presence of a band of iron precipitation at the subsurface (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).

Wash and transfer the isolated filaments into the autoclaved sediment
Timing: 1 h
The following procedure describes the steps followed to further wash the isolated CB filaments and transfer the filaments into the autoclaved sediment.
Transfer the isolated CB filaments to a droplet of the washing solution placed on a microscopic slide (Methods video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3]).
Use a clean glass needle to scrape the biomass off the glass hook.
Resuspend the biomass in the droplet of the washing solution.
Note: Washing solution can be autoclaved seawater, artificial seawater, phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) solution, or DI water.
If necessary, repeat step 10 until the biomass appears free of sediment particles.
Use another clean glass needle to pick up the washed biomass and transfer the biomass into the surface layer of the autoclaved sediment (Methods video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3]).
Increase the probability of transferred CB survival by performing multiple transfers into the surface layer of the autoclaved sediment.
Optional: A sterilized inoculation needle can be used to transfer the CB biomass.

Culture inoculated sediment and evaluate the growth of cable bacteria
Timing: 3 weeks or longer
The following procedure describes the steps required to culture inoculated sediment and to evaluate the growth of cable bacteria.

Slowly submerge the inoculated sediment into an aerated aquarium filled with an autoclaved medium.
Culture the inoculated sediment. Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Evaluate the growth and presence of CB by measuring the vertical chemical profiles of oxygen, sulfide, and pH.
Note: The vertical chemical profiles of oxygen, sulfide, and pH that are characteristic of CB can be measured by the microelectrodes. More details about performing microelectrode profiling in a lab can be found in Malkin et al. (2014)[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11] and Li et al. (2020a, 2020b)[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]; .
Alternatives: Artificial seawater can also be used as the culture media in commercially available aquarium tanks. The presence of CB can also be verified by using microscopic techniques (e.g., scanning electronic microscopy and transmission electron microscopy) to identify their unique morphological features namely the longitudinal ridges and cartwheel cell-cell junctions (Li et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]; Pfeffer et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib21]), molecular techniques (e.g., fluorescent in situ hybridization) (Li et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]; Malkin et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11], 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]), and sequencing techniques (e.g., maker gene analysis and metagenomics) (Geelhoed et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]; Kjeldsen et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]; Li et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]; Trojan et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib28]). The growth and density of CB can be evaluated using counts of stained filaments and quantitative polymerase chain reaction methods (Aller et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]; Geelhoed et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]).
